Guidelines recommend continued avoidance of contact sports until 10 days after the trauma or until the patient has been asymptomatic while taking no medication for a period of 7 days. This patient meets both time-based criteria, is asymptomatic with normal findings on neurologic examination, and may be cleared to return to play.
Although brain MRI (
Option A

) is more diagnostically accurate than head CT in the setting of subacute or chronic headache, a patient without symptoms or abnormal examination findings after a mild TBI does not require imaging before return to play.
There are many published indications for head CT (
Option C

) in the setting of acute head injury, such as age greater than 60 years, progressive headache, seizure, repeated vomiting after the trauma, persistent drowsiness or amnesia, focal deficits, and certain dangerous mechanisms of injury. This patient, however, sustained the TBI 10 days ago and had none of these indications, so head CT is unnecessary.
Neuropsychological testing (
Option D
) is valuable in the assessment of patients remaining symptomatic after a mild TBI, but this patient has returned to baseline and needs no such testing.
Vestibular therapy (
Option E
) may be valuable in the management of patients with persistent posttraumatic dizziness or gait imbalance. This patient exhibits no symptoms or signs of ongoing vestibular dysfunction.

objective.__html: Assess “return to play” following mild traumatic brain injury in athletes.

references: Mullally WJ. Concussion. Am J Med. 2017 Aug;130(8):885-92. Epub 2017 May 11.

title: Question 24

children: A 55-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital for paralysis present on awakening from anesthesia after surgical repair of an aortic dissection. He reports midthoracic back pain. He had been well without evidence of infection before surgery. Other medical problems include hypertension and dyslipidemia. Current medications are atorvastatin, hydrochlorothiazide, and losartan.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Muscle tone is flaccid in the legs and normal in the arms. Muscle strength is normal in both arms and no movement in both legs. Reflexes are 2+ in arms and 0 in legs. Sensation to pinprick is mildly impaired in the legs, and vibratory and position sensation are intact.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Spinal cord infarction can occur as a consequence of hypotension during cardiovascular or aortic surgery.
Anterior infarction of the spinal cord typically results in acute, bilateral, flaccid paralysis.
The most likely diagnosis is spinal cord infarction (
Option D

). The most common clinical presentation of a spinal cord infarction involves the anterior spinal artery. Prolonged hypotension during cardiovascular or aortic surgery can result in lack of perfusion to watershed regions of the spinal cord. In this patient, the infarction likely occurred as a consequence of hypoperfusion to the spinal cord vasculature in the anterior arterial vascular distribution in the setting of repair of an aortic dissection. The midportion of the thoracic spinal cord is especially prone to hypoperfusion infarction where the anterior spinal artery from above meets the radicular artery of Adamkiewicz from below. Hypoperfusion in the anterior arterial vascular distribution of the cord typically interrupts both descending motor pathways and the anterior horn cells in the gray matter of the cord, resulting in acute, bilateral, flaccid (low tone, hyporeflexia) paralysis. If sensation is impaired, it will not involve the posterior columns (vibration, position) because of separate vascular supply to the posterior cord.
Guillain-Barré syndrome (
Option A

) is not a likely diagnosis. This inflammatory polyradiculopathy is typified by a subacute onset with progressive ascending paralysis. This patient's acute onset of symptoms is not consistent with the subacute ascending paralysis typical of Guillain-Barré syndrome. Guillain-Barré syndrome also typically occurs as a postinfectious syndrome, and this patient did not experience a preceding infection.
Idiopathic transverse myelitis (
Option B

) is an unlikely explanation for the patient's symptoms. Although this entity could potentially result in a similar set of findings on examination, the time course of an acute onset and the association of the patient's symptoms with concurrent aortic surgery make a vascular cause far more likely than an inflammatory myelitis, which would have a more subacute onset and is typically a postinfectious phenomenon.
Lumbar disk herniation (
Option C

) is an unlikely cause for this patient's weakness. Lumbar disk herniations typically result in radiculopathy or cauda equina syndrome, neither of which would result in complete plegia of all muscles in both lower extremities. Further, such pathology would also likely result in sensory deficits, which this patient is not experiencing.

references: Romi F, Naess H. Spinal cord infarction in clinical neurology: a review of characteristics and long-term prognosis in comparison to cerebral infarction. Eur Neurol. 2016;76:95-8.

title: Question 25

children: A 60-year-old woman comes to the office to discuss the best strategy to prevent cognitive impairment. She has no medical problems and takes no medications. She does not use tobacco, has 1 to 2 alcoholic drinks per week, and is sedentary.
On physical examination, vital signs and other findings are unremarkable.
Results of cognitive screening testing are normal.
Which of the following is the most effective preventive measure?
Physical exercise is the most important modifiable lifestyle factor to prevent the onset of cognitive impairment.
Medications, vitamin, and herbal supplements do not prevent cognitive decline in healthy people or in patients with mild cognitive impairment.
The most important measure to help this patient prevent dementia is to begin a regular program of physical exercise (
Option C

). With the growth of the aging population, the prevalence of mild cognitive impairment and dementia is increasing. However, the incidence of dementia is declining with the control of vascular risk factors (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia). Adjustments to diet will mitigate many of the risk factors for developing cognitive decline. Diets rich in fruits and vegetables, unsaturated fats, fish and whole-grain cereal products are being studied and show some promise for increasing brain health. However, these benefits have not been confirmed. Exercise is the most important modifiable lifestyle factor to prevent the onset of cognitive impairment. Results from systematic reviews suggest that exercise training is associated with moderate positive effects for global cognition, logical memory, inhibitory control, and divided attention. Even exercise that is initiated in mid to late life can still provide benefits. The 2018 Physical Activity Guidelines for Americans recommend that adults perform at least 150 to 300 minutes per week of moderate-intensity exercise. Other options include 75 to 150 minutes per week of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity or equivalent combinations of moderate- and vigorous-intensity exercise.

Although evidence suggests that higher educational attainment and mid-life intellectual and social activities lead to more late-life cognitive reserve, there is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of any individual cognitive intervention strategy (
Option A
) in the prevention of cognitive impairment.
There is no role for donepezil (
Option B
) or any other pharmacologic agent in preventing cognitive decline in patients with normal cognitive function.
In patients with MCI, use of vitamin E 2000 U daily (
Option D

) is ineffective for reducing progression to Alzheimer disease. In the absence of a specific vitamin deficiency, there is no role for herbal or vitamin supplementation to prevent cognitive decline in adults without cognitive impairment.

references: Kivipelto M, Mangialasche F, Ngandu T. Lifestyle interventions to prevent cognitive impairment, dementia and Alzheimer disease. Nat Rev Neurol. 2018;14(11):653–66.

title: Question 26

children: A 39-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-month history of low energy, lack of interest in activities, and poor sleep. She has relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis and a history of vitamin D deficiency. Medications are glatiramer acetate and a vitamin D supplement.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. All other examination findings, including those from a neurologic examination, are unremarkable.
Two weeks ago, a routine MRI of the brain showed a stable number of T2 lesions, and none of these lesions demonstrated contrast enhancement on T1-weighted images.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Depression is very common in patients with multiple sclerosis, and clinicians should be vigilant for the signs of depression, and if present, screen for suicidality.
The most appropriate management is to screen for depression (
Option C

). This patient presents with signs of depression, including low energy, lack of interest in activities, and poor sleep. Major depression is very common in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and likely occurs in approximately 50% of patients during their lifetime. Approximately 10% of patients with MS have experienced persistent thoughts of suicide. Furthermore, the suicide rate for patients with MS and depression is elevated compared with that of patients with depression only. MS-related depression is likely multifactorial, involving the emotional response to dealing with a chronic disease, the consequence of demyelinating lesions and inflammatory cytokines on neurotransmitter function, and the adverse effects of treatments (such as interferon beta). Clinicians should be vigilant for the signs of depression, and if present, screen for suicidality. If suicidal ideation is present, the lethality of the ideation should be evaluated. Clinicians should have a low threshold for initiating antidepressants and offering referrals to psychiatry or psychology for counseling. Referral to a psychiatrist is indicated for patients with severe depression, failure of initial therapy, complex psychiatric comorbidities, and high suicide risk.
Initiation of modafinil (
Option A

) is not indicated. Although this patient reports low energy, and fatigue is a common symptom in MS, fatigue is not the only potential cause of her presenting symptoms. Patients with MS who are experiencing fatigue should be evaluated for depression and sleep disturbances before initiation of treatment for fatigue.
Measuring this patient's serum 25-hydroxy vitamin D level (
Option B

) is not the most appropriate next step in management. Although the patient has a history of vitamin D deficiency, and optimization of vitamin D levels may have some benefit in patients with MS, the patient's presenting symptom of depression is not a symptom commonly associated with vitamin D deficiency, and deficiency is unlikely in a patient taking supplementation.
Discontinuing glatiramer acetate and initiating natalizumab (
Option D
) is not indicated. The patient does not have any new disease activity, and results of her MRI show stable lesions.

objective.__html: Screen for depression in a patient with multiple sclerosis.

references: Kalb R, Feinstein A, Rohrig A, Sankary L, Willis A. Depression and suicidality in multiple sclerosis: red flags, management strategies, and ethical considerations. Curr Neurol Neurosci Rep. 2019 Aug 28;19(10):77. doi:10.1007/s11910-019-0992-1. PMID: 31463644

title: Question 27

children: A 72-year-old woman is hospitalized for an acute stroke; symptoms have been present for 24 hours. She has chronic hypertension. Current medications are amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide.

On physical examination, temperature is normal and blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg (decreased from 170/90 mm Hg at presentation); the remaining vital signs are normal. Oxygen saturation is 97% with the patient breathing ambient air. Left facial weakness, no movement in the left arm and leg, and decreased pinprick sensation on the left side are noted. Mental status is normal. A bedside swallow examination is positive for dysphagia. The patient is incontinent of urine.
CT scan of the head shows an acute intracerebral hemorrhage in the right thalamus, which has remained stable at 24 hours.
Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
Patients with acute stroke, including patients with intracerebral hemorrhage, are at increased risk for venous thromboembolism.
Venous thromboembolism prevention should be initiated for patients with acute stroke on the day of hospital admission.
The most appropriate management is venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis (
Option D

). Patients with acute stroke, including patients with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), are at increased risk for VTE. In patients with acute stroke, guidelines recommend intermittent pneumatic compression beginning the day of hospital admission. Intermittent pneumatic compression is superior to either knee-high or thigh-high compression stockings in the prevention of VTE. After 24 hours, if there is no evidence of hematoma expansion, then subcutaneous pharmacoprophylaxis (typically, low-molecular-weight heparin) is recommended for VTE prophylaxis.

Dysphagia is a common complication of stroke and is a major risk factor for developing aspiration pneumonia. A bedside water swallowing test is often a sufficient screening test for dysphagia until more sophisticated diagnostic testing, such as video fluoroscopy, can assess the severity of dysphagia. This patient should not begin oral feeding (
Option A
) following a positive bedside dysphagia screening test until further evaluation is completed.
Routine placement of a bladder catheter (
Option B

) in acutely ill hospitalized patients is not recommended. Indications for bladder catheterization have been established and include conditions such as acute or chronic urinary retention, treatment of significant pressure injury complicated by urinary incontinence, and need for hourly urine output measurements. This patient has no indication for bladder catheterization.
A 2018 systematic review found that supplemental oxygen (
Option C

) in patients with normal oxygen saturation as measured by pulse oximetry increases mortality in patients with stroke. The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association recommends oxygen to maintain an oxygen saturation of 94% or greater. Other guidelines recommend against starting oxygen therapy in patients at or above 93% saturation and discontinuing oxygen if saturation is at or above 96%. This patient has no indication for supplemental oxygen therapy.

objective.__html: Prevent deep venous thrombosis following acute stroke.

references: Schünemann HJ, Cushman M, Burnett AE, et al. American Society of Hematology 2018 guidelines for management of venous thromboembolism: prophylaxis for hospitalized and nonhospitalized medical patients. Blood Adv. 2018;2:3198-3225.
doi:10.1182/bloodadvances.2018022954

title: Question 28

children: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-year history of progressively worsening memory impairment. She can no longer handle her finances, as she doesn't remember how to fill out checks properly. She lives with her spouse and is independent in all other basic activities of daily living.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Montreal Cognitive Assessment score is 21/30, with difficulty copying the cube, recalling the five words, and naming the day, date, and month noted.
Results of laboratory evaluation are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate imaging test to perform next?

text.__html: MRI of the brain without contrast

children: Patients with evidence of dementia symptoms for less than 3 years should have advanced neuroimaging with noncontrast CT or MRI.
MRI of the brain supports the diagnosis of Alzheimer disease when it shows evidence of decreased volume of the hippocampi out of proportion to rest of the brain.
Either a brain MRI or a head CT without contrast (
Option D

) should be done in the evaluation of dementia. Guidelines recommend that patients with evidence of dementia symptoms for less than 3 years should have advanced neuroimaging with noncontrast CT or MRI. Neuroimaging can identify conditions that may be remediable or modifiable, such as cerebrovascular disease, hemorrhage, tumor, and abscess. Neuroimaging can also support the diagnoses of specific dementias, such as Alzheimer disease, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, and hydrocephalus. MRI of the brain supports the diagnosis of Alzheimer disease when it shows evidence of decreased volume of the hippocampi out of proportion to rest of the brain. This patient likely has Alzheimer disease, and although a head CT is acceptable, brain MRI would be better to define the level of atrophy in the hippocampi for this diagnosis.
An amyloid-specific PET scan (
Option A
) uses

F-fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) to detect amyloid plaques. Amyloid PET scanning is not routinely recommended in the evaluation of dementia. However, this imaging modality can help differentiate frontotemporal dementia from Alzheimer disease when the correct diagnosis is not clinically apparent. An amyloid PET scan, although FDA-approved, is not covered by insurance.
When the MRI is normal and the diagnosis is in question or a non–Alzheimer disease process is being considered, a functional fluorodeoxyglucose PET scan (
Option B

) can be used to look for the Alzheimer disease pattern of decreased brain function in the bilateral parietal and temporal regions. However, it is typically not an appropriate assessment until structural lesions in the brain are assessed by either MRI of the brain or head CT.
A head CT with contrast (
Option C
) is not necessary unless there is concern for infection, inflammation, or neoplasm, which would typically be accompanied by focal neurologic findings on examination.

references: Oh ES, Rabins PV. Dementia.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 29

children: A 55-year-old man with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis is evaluated for a slow, labored gait that began after a relapse 1 year ago. The symptom has not worsened during this time, but he reports that it interferes with his ability to keep up with the physical demands of his job. His only medication is dimethyl fumarate.

Physical examination reveals increased tone in the left leg. Muscle strength is 4/5 with hip flexion and ankle dorsiflexion. Gait is slow, and there is a slight outward swing of the left leg when ambulating. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following interventions is most likely to improve this patient's ambulation?
In patients with multiple sclerosis with ambulatory dysfunction, dalfampridine can improve gait speed and endurance.
The benefit of disease-modifying therapies is reducing risk for future relapses, MRI activity or disability progression, not symptomatic improvement of existing disability.
The intervention most likely to improve this patient's ambulatory function is dalfampridine (
Option A

). Maintenance of mobility in MS patients is essential to maintaining quality of life. An active healthy lifestyle is necessary to help stave off future disability. Physical and occupational therapy can provide gait safety training and improve balance and endurance. Assistive devices, such as braces, canes, walkers, and electrostimulatory walk-assist devices, can provide additional benefit. This patient's left leg findings are consistent with injury to the corticospinal tract from a prior relapse. Dalfampridine, an oral voltage-gated potassium channel antagonist, can improve gait speed and endurance in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS) with ambulatory dysfunction. Dalfampridine cannot induce healing or remyelination. However, this medication likely improves neuronal conduction, allowing signals to be processed through the corticospinal tract more efficiently and thus leading to improvements in gait in those with injury to this tract. Dalfampridine has a rare risk of seizures and should not be used in patients with known epilepsy or with kidney impairment.
Initiation of modafinil (
Option B
) would not be an appropriate intervention at this time. This medication has potential benefit for those with fatigue related to MS, but it has no demonstrated efficacy for improvement in gait.
MS spasticity is due to corticospinal tract damage, resulting in increased muscle tone, painful muscle cramps, spasms, and contractures. The use of muscle relaxants, such as tizanidine (
Option C
), baclofen, cyclobenzaprine, and the benzodiazepines, may be helpful. However, this patient is not reporting painful muscle spasms or cramps, and these drugs are not proven to improve gait function.
Altering the patient's disease-modifying therapy, such as switching to natalizumab (
Option D
) or ocrelizumab (
Option E

), would not be appropriate in this setting. Although these disease-modifying therapies have high efficacy, none have demonstrated benefit for symptomatic improvement for long-standing neurologic deficits. The benefit of these disease-modifying therapies is in prevention—reducing risk for future relapses, MRI activity, or disability progression. Altering this patient's disease-modifying therapy would thus not help improve his gait, which has been affected for 1 year.

objective.__html: Treat gait dysfunction in multiple sclerosis.

references: Shi J, Wu X, Chen Y. Study on dalfampridine in the treatment of multiple sclerosis mobility disability: a meta-analysis. PLoS One. 2019;14(9):e0222288. Published 2019 Sep 12.
doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0222288

title: Question 30

children: A 74-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital at 2:00
AM

for agitation. She was admitted 3 days ago with acute diverticulitis. Over the last 24 hours, the patient has been alternately agitated or drowsy, sometimes confused when awake, and tonight has experienced visual hallucinations. Her only other medical problem is long-standing depression treated with paroxetine, which has been discontinued. Medical records indicate she does not drink alcohol. Her current medications include oxycodone, scheduled every 6 hours, and piperacillin-tazobactam.

On physical examination, temperature is 37.2 °C (99.0 °F), and the remaining vital signs are normal. Oxygen saturation is 97% with the patient breathing ambient air. The abdomen has diminished but present bowel sounds, and there is mild tenderness to palpation without guarding in the left lower quadrant. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. The patient is alert and vigilant but inattentive to questioning and demonstrates disorganized thinking.
An order is written to hold the oxycodone.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
Withdrawal from alcohol or other abused drugs and from prescribed medications can precipitate delirium.
The most appropriate next step in management is the addition of paroxetine (
Option C

). The patient shows signs of delirium, such as fluctuations in mentation, nighttime sleeplessness, and hallucinations. Treatment of delirium involves identifying and treating its underlying causes. In the elderly, medications are a common precipitating cause of delirium in hospitalized patients. Sedating medications, including opioids, can precipitate or worsen delirium, and holding or reducing the patient's overall dose of oxycodone is a reasonable first step in addressing her delirium. Withdrawal of alcohol and drugs such as benzodiazepines, opioids, and antidepressants can also precipitate delirium. Antidepressant medications should be gradually tapered to avoid discontinuation syndrome. Discontinuation symptoms can occur with any selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor but is most commonly reported with paroxetine. The most common symptoms are dizziness, fatigue, and headache. Other commonly reported symptoms are agitation, anxiety, and insomnia. Symptoms may start from 1 to 7 days following abrupt discontinuation of antidepressant medications. Paroxetine should be reintroduced.

Other classes of drugs that have been implicated in precipitating delirium in hospitalized patients include benzodiazepines and drugs with anticholinergic properties. Drugs with anticholinergic properties are associated with well-known adverse effects, particularly in the elderly, yet are commonly prescribed. Frequently reported central nervous system adverse effects include memory impairment, confusion, and hallucinations. First-generation antihistamines, such as diphenhydramine (
Option A

), are often prescribed to induce sedation and sleep in the elderly. However, these drugs have anticholinergic properties and, according to the American Geriatrics Society, are among the drugs to be avoided in the elderly.
Sedative hypnotic drugs, such as lorazepam (
Option B
) and zolpidem (
Option D
), should be avoided in older patients because of their propensity to cause or worsen delirium. They should not be started in this patient.

Studies of hospitalized patients with acute delirium have documented a mean of three precipitating causes of delirium per patient in two thirds of carefully evaluated patients. While holding the oxycodone is appropriate, careful evaluation of other causes of delirium should be undertaken. No additional treatment (
Option E
) is not the best option.

objective.__html: Treat delirium in a hospitalized patient.

references: Marcantonio ER. Delirium in hospitalized older adults. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:1456-66.

title: Question 31

children: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for a 1-hour history of a severe headache. He has had similar headaches for the past 2 weeks that start in the evening, last 2 to 3 hours, and are characterized by intense left-sided pain that is periorbital and piercing. Associated features are photophobia, nausea, and ipsilateral tearing. Nasal sumatriptan, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen have not relieved the pain. He has a 7-pack-year smoking history.
On physical examination, vital signs are within normal limits. Left ptosis and miosis are noted.
Results of laboratory studies and MRI of the brain with contrast are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Magnetic resonance angiography of the head and neck

children: Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias are characterized by severe pain localized to the periorbital or temporal areas and associated with autonomic features, such as nasal congestion or rhinorrhea and ptosis or miosis; cluster headache is the most common subtype.
Subcutaneous sumatriptan and oxygen inhalation are effective treatments of cluster headache and are indicated as first-line treatments of attacks.
The most appropriate management is subcutaneous sumatriptan (
Option D

). The clinical presentation is classic for episodic cluster headache, the most common of the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs). Male gender and tobacco use are risk factors for cluster headache. Diagnostic criteria require one to eight daily episodes lasting 15 to 180 minutes when untreated. The pain is unilateral and severe and orbital, supraorbital, or temporal in location. Associated features must include at least one ipsilateral cranial autonomic feature (lacrimation, nasal stuffiness or rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection, ptosis, miosis) and/or a sense of restlessness or agitation. Cluster headache has a cyclical nature in which periods of recurrent headache activity are interrupted by months to years of headache remission. Many of the attacks are nocturnal, and some may be provoked by alcohol ingestion. When cluster headache (or any TAC) is suspected, brain MRI is necessary to rule out structural mimics. Subcutaneous sumatriptan and 100% oxygen inhalation are both effective for cluster headache and indicated as first-line treatments of attacks.
Carbamazepine (
Option A
) is a first-line treatment for trigeminal neuralgia, but the length of this patient's episodes and the presence of autonomic features are not compatible with this diagnosis.
Several headache conditions are uniquely responsive to indomethacin (
Option B

), but cluster headache is not among them. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania is a TAC related to cluster headache that is indomethacin responsive, but episodes are shorter in duration (2-30 minutes) and higher in frequency (5-20 per day) compared with cluster headache. Hemicrania continua and primary cough headache are other examples of indomethacin-responsive headache disorders.
Carotid angiography and magnet resonance angiography (MRA) of the head and neck (
Option C

) are preferred options in the evaluation of cervical artery dissections. Although the differential diagnosis of a headache with ptosis and miosis (partial Horner syndrome) includes carotid artery dissection, this diagnosis is unlikely with a pattern of daily, brief, episodic headaches over a span of 2 weeks.

references: Hoffmann J, May A. Diagnosis, pathophysiology, and management of cluster headache. Lancet Neurol. 2018 Jan;17(1):75-83.

title: Question 32

children: A 76-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a stroke. She is given intravenous alteplase within 3 hours of onset. She also has hypertension. Her only outpatient medication is amlodipine.
On physical examination, temperature is 37.6 °C (99.7 °F), blood pressure is 160/76 mm Hg, pulse rate is 68/min and irregular, and

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: oxygen saturation

is 96% with the patient breathing ambient air. She has global aphasia with no speech production, right facial weakness, and lack of movement in right arm and leg. National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score is 18.
ECG shows atrial fibrillation.
CT of the head shows no acute findings.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step management?
Patients eligible for alteplase should receive alteplase even if mechanical thrombectomy is being considered.
In patients who meet eligibility requirements, thrombectomy after thrombolysis is associated with improved neurologic outcomes.
The most appropriate management is CT angiography of the brain (
Option A

). The patient is seen because of an acute ischemic stroke within 3 hours of onset and was appropriately treated with intravenous alteplase. Patients eligible for alteplase should receive alteplase even if mechanical thrombectomy is being considered. She has had a large stroke, with a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score of 18, and has examination findings consistent with a large-vessel (middle cerebral or intracranial carotid artery) occlusion, including aphasia. A large-vessel occlusion is associated with lower rates of neurologic improvement and recanalization with alteplase; treatment with thrombectomy after thrombolysis is indicated and associated with improved neurologic outcomes. In patients with a large-vessel occlusion, thrombectomy should be considered within 6 hours after symptom onset if noncontrast CT of the head shows no extensive infarction. Thrombectomy can be considered in select patients not treated with thrombolysis in a 6- to 24-hour time-of-onset window. A large-vessel occlusion can be identified only with vascular imaging; CT angiography is indicated in patients with a suspicion of a large-vessel occlusion on the basis of examination.
Intravenous heparin (
Option B

) is not appropriate because the patient has received intravenous thrombolysis, and any antithrombotic agent should be held within the first 24 hours in order to reduce hemorrhagic complications. The patient likely has new-onset atrial fibrillation and in the long term should receive anticoagulation for stroke prevention; in the acute setting, however, anticoagulation is not associated with a reduced risk for stroke and is associated with a higher risk for hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke.
Intravenous labetalol (
Option C

) should not be administered because the patient's blood pressure is less than the recommended threshold of 180/105 mm Hg following thrombolytic therapy. Acute treatment to lower it is therefore not indicated.
Providing no additional therapy (
Option D
) for this patient is not the best option because thrombectomy may result in improved neurologic outcomes.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient with acute ischemic stroke for thrombectomy.

references: Powers WJ, Rabinstein AA, Ackerson T, et al; American Heart Association Stroke Council. 2018 Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke: A Guideline for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. Stroke. 2018;49:e46-e110.

title: Question 33

children: A 78-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department after a fall. He has Parkinson disease treated with carbidopa-levodopa. Since he started this treatment 2 months ago, tremor and walking have improved, but he feels lightheaded upon standing. He also has type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. Current medications are carbidopa-levodopa, metformin, and atorvastatin.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 140/80 mm Hg sitting and 80/65 mm Hg standing. Pulse rate is 84/min. A mild right-sided tremor at rest is noted. His gait is slow with a narrow pace without shuffling or freezing. He can walk in tandem and stabilizes himself against backward pull on his shoulders.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to prevent further falls?
Patients with Parkinson disease and falls should be assessed for postural imbalance, impaired stepping, freezing of gait, and orthostatic hypotension.
In patients with Parkinson disease who experience severe peripheral side effects of levodopa, such as orthostatic hypotension, higher carbidopa doses can alleviate these symptoms.
The most appropriate next step to prevent additional falls is to increase the dosage of carbidopa (
Option E

). Patients with Parkinson disease and falls, such as this patient, should be assessed for postural imbalance, impaired stepping, freezing of gait, and orthostatic hypotension. This patient's history of lightheadedness on standing and substantial drop in standing blood pressure suggests orthostatic hypotension as the likely cause of his fall. Examination reveals no freezing of gait or postural impairment, findings that are often noted in more advanced Parkinson disease. Orthostatic hypotension in Parkinson disease can be due to disease-related autonomic dysfunction, comorbidities (such as diabetic autonomic neuropathy), or a peripheral effect of levodopa. Symptom onset after initiation of levodopa therapy should alert clinicians to this potential drug-related adverse effect. Carbidopa blocks the adverse effects of levodopa outside the brain and is always administered in combination with levodopa. However, in patients with severe peripheral side effects of levodopa, such as orthostatic hypotension, higher carbidopa doses can alleviate these symptoms.
Droxidopa (
Option A
) and fludrocortisone (
Option B

) can be used for symptomatic management of neurogenic orthostatic hypotension and would be the appropriate next options if additional carbidopa is ineffective. However, unlike carbidopa, these medications are associated with risk for supine hypertension; therefore, a carbidopa trial should be prioritized.
Gabapentin (
Option C
) can improve neuropathic pain and paresthesia but has no role in improving autonomic neuropathy or preventing falls.
Dopamine agonists, such as pramipexole (
Option D

), can cause orthostatic hypotension and are likely to aggravate the risk for falls in this patient. This drug would have been an appropriate option if the falls were related to motor symptoms of Parkinson disease, such as shuffling and freezing, rather than orthostatic hypotension. In addition, it is important to ensure levodopa therapy is optimized before considering adding other medications.

objective.__html: Manage drug-related orthostatic hypotension in Parkinson disease.

references: Seppi K, Ray Chaudhuri K, Coelho M, et al; the collaborators of the Parkinson's Disease Update on Non-Motor Symptoms Study Group on behalf of the Movement Disorders Society Evidence-Based Medicine Committee. Update on treatments for nonmotor symptoms of Parkinson's disease-an evidence-based medicine review. Mov Disord. 2019;34:180-98.

title: Question 34

children: A 26-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-month history of jerking episodes that occur three to four times monthly. The jerking lasts less than 1 second. He is aware during the episodes and retains a complete memory of the event. He reports that sometimes the jerking occurs in clusters and he will have 10 to 20 jerks over a period of 30 to 90 seconds, often on awakening from sleep. He denies confusion or loss of muscle tone with either the single or clustered events. He has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal. The neurologic examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Characteristic clinical findings of myoclonus are brief (<1 second), “shock-like” involuntary movements caused by muscular contractions.
Myoclonus and retained awareness are the defining manifestations of myoclonic seizures.
The most likely diagnosis is myoclonic seizures (
Option C

), which typically have very short duration (<1 second) with retained awareness. Characteristic clinical findings of myoclonus are brief, “shock-like” involuntary movements caused by muscular contractions (positive myoclonus) or inhibitions (negative myoclonus, [e.g., asterixis]). Positive myoclonus is the defining seizure manifestation of myoclonic seizures. When describing symptoms, patients will usually use words like “twitches”, “spasms,” “jerks,” or even “shakes.” Patients are often described as “clumsy” before establishing the diagnosis of myoclonic seizure, since suddenly dropping items is a common symptom. Myoclonic seizures are considered generalized seizures, which involve the entire body. They may occur more often on awakening, and recording an electroencephalogram (EEG) after a period of sleep may help capture evidence of the seizure for diagnostic confirmation. Myoclonus should not be confused with myoclonic seizures; myoclonus is a single muscle group twitch that may be focal or generalized, but which may or may not represent a seizure. For example, benign myoclonus of sleep, the so-called hypnic jerks commonly experienced when falling asleep, are normal; unlike with a myoclonic seizure, the EEG pattern would be normal during the myoclonic event.
Focal motor aware seizures (
Option A

), previously known as complex partial seizures, typically originate in the frontal lobe, where the motor cortex controls contralateral limb movement. By definition, the shaking of these seizures is rhythmic, repetitive, and unilateral. Similar to JME, patients with focal motor seizures are alert and responsive.
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) (
Option B

) are typically characterized by abrupt loss of consciousness, whole body stiffening followed by shaking, and, unlike this patient's myoclonic seizures, a typical duration of 1 to 3 minutes. Also, unlike myoclonic seizures, GTCS are characterized by altered awareness and post-event confusion.
Tonic seizures (
Option D

) are also short, lasting only a few seconds, and are associated with generalized muscle stiffening. Tonic seizures are typically painful if awareness is retained, although awareness is typically altered and leads to falling. Tonic seizures typically occur in patients with neurologic developmental disabilities and epilepsies with multiple seizure types; this patient is an otherwise neurologically healthy adult with brief episodes of myoclonus without impairment of consciousness.

references: Baykan B, Wolf P. Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy as a spectrum disorder: A focused review. Seizure. 2017;49:36–41.

title: Question 35

children: A 64-year-old man is hospitalized for right-sided weakness and slurred speech of 24 hours' duration. He has hypertension and dyslipidemia. Current medications are aspirin and high-intensity atorvastatin.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 190/88 mm Hg and

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)
children: oxygen saturation

is 98% with the patient breathing ambient air. The remaining vital signs are normal. Abnormal physical examination findings are confined to right facial weakness and right arm and leg pronator drift. National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score is 3.
ECG is normal.
Serum creatinine
level is 0.9 mg/dL (79.6 µmol/L), and cardiac biomarkers are negative.
CT scan of the head shows a left frontal infarction. CT angiogram shows 80% stenosis of middle cerebral artery.
Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate treatment?

In patients not eligible for thrombolytic therapy, the blood pressure (BP) threshold for initiating antihypertensive therapy is greater than 220/120 mm Hg; reduction of BP by 15% during the first 24 hours may then be reasonable.
The most appropriate immediate action is no further intervention or treatment (
Option E

). The patient has had a minor ischemic stroke (National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale score of 3) due to high-grade stenosis of the middle cerebral artery. He is receiving the most appropriate medical therapy, including aspirin and a high-intensity statin. In the long term, the patient will require control of hypertension. A target blood pressure less than 130/80 mm Hg is considered a reasonable therapeutic target for most patients. In the first 48 hours, however, and especially in patients with symptomatic intracranial stenosis, lowering blood pressure is associated with neurologic worsening.
Furosemide, chlorthalidone, and lisinopril (
Options A-C

) are not appropriate because blood pressure lowering in the acute setting is associated with neurologic worsening. Acute lowering of blood pressure is indicated if clinical findings suggest end-organ damage, including active ischemic coronary disease, heart failure, aortic dissection, or hypertensive encephalopathy. Treatment in the acute setting is also indicated in patients who are receiving intravenous alteplase, to maintain the blood pressure less than 180/105 mm Hg. In others, treatment is indicated if blood pressure exceeds 220/120 mm Hg. In these patients, it might be reasonable to lower blood pressure by 15% during the first 24 hours after onset of stroke. For this patient with recent minor noncardioembolic ischemic stroke, dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus clopidogrel) should be initiated early (at least within 7 days of onset) and continued for 21 to 90 days, followed by aspirin to reduce the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke.
Intracranial stenting (
Option D

) of symptomatic intracranial arterial stenosis is not appropriate because it is associated with a high risk for procedural stroke and no long-term reduction in risk for subsequent stroke. Stenting can be considered on a case-by-case basis if the patient has additional infarcts despite adherence to best medical therapy.

objective.__html: Manage elevated blood pressure in a patient with ischemic stroke.

references: Powers WJ, Rabinstein AA, Ackerson T, et al; American Heart Association Stroke Council. 2018 Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke: A Guideline for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. Stroke. 2018;49:e46-e110.

title: Question 36

children: A 44-year-old man is evaluated for muscle cramps and fatigue. He frequently experiences cramps after prolonged exertion. Within the past few months he has developed difficulty climbing stairs and feels that his walking has become unsteady. He has no family history of neuromuscular disease.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is no muscle tenderness on palpation. Muscle strength is reduced in bilateral hip flexors and arm abductors and preserved distally. Deep tendon reflexes are preserved but exhibit delayed relaxation. Percussion over biceps muscles leads to formation of a raised muscular ridge. Gait has a waddling quality. Sensory examination and muscle tone are normal. Plantar responses are flexor. There are no involuntary movements.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
Hypothyroid myopathy is associated with proximal symmetric weakness, myalgia, and cramps without sensory loss or upper motor neuron signs, and muscle mounding after percussion (myoedema).
Myopathy may be the only manifestation of hypothyroidism.
The most likely cause of this patient's findings is hypothyroidism, and the most likely diagnosis is hypothyroid myopathy (
Option C

). The clinical presentation of proximal symmetric weakness, myalgia, and cramps without sensory loss or upper motor neuron signs is consistent with a myopathy. In this patient, the finding of muscle mounding after percussion (myoedema) strongly suggests hypothyroidism. The diagnosis of primary hypothyroidism is made by measuring serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level and, if elevated, measuring the level of serum free thyroxine (T

). Clinical symptoms and signs can be nonspecific, often resulting in a delayed diagnosis. If asked, most patients do have muscular symptoms (stiffness, myalgias, cramps, easy fatigability), and muscle symptoms may be the predominant or the only clinical manifestation of hypothyroidism. If measured, serum creatine kinase is elevated in many patients with hypothyroidism, but the degree of elevation does not always correlate with the severity of muscle symptoms. Other features that may be seen with hypothyroid myopathy include goiter, ptosis, enlarged muscle bulk, and delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes (Woltman sign).
Copper deficiency (
Option A

) can lead to myeloneuropathy associated with large-fiber sensory deficit, ataxia, and brisk reflexes. In this patient, proximal weakness, intact sensory examination, and absence of upper motor neuron signs (such as the extensor plantar response and hyperreflexia) are inconsistent with copper deficiency.
Hypokalemia (
Option B

) can be associated with muscle weakness and cramps. However, this patient's myoedema is not a typical feature of hypokalemia. Hypokalemic periodic paralysis is a rare genetic disorder associated with episodic weakness.
Vitamin D deficiency (
Option D
) can be associated with myalgia and proximal weakness. Myoedema is not a feature of vitamin D deficiency.
Vitamin E deficiency (
Option E
) can cause myelopathy and peripheral neuropathy, but myopathy with proximal weakness is not typical. This patient does not exhibit signs of myeloneuropathy.

references: Sindoni A, Rodolico C, Pappalardo MA, et al. Hypothyroid myopathy: a peculiar clinical presentation of thyroid failure. Review of the literature. Rev Endocr Metab Disord. 2016;17:499-519.

title: Question 37

children: A 63-year-old man is evaluated for myalgia and proximal weakness in both upper and lower extremities. He has diabetes, hypertension, and coronary artery disease. Current medications include metformin, empagliflozin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg; other vital signs are normal. Proximal muscle tenderness is noted. All other findings, including those from the neurologic examination, are normal.
Laboratory studies show an
erythrocyte sedimentation rate
of 15 mm/h,
hemoglobin A
1c
level of 6.8%, and
serum creatine kinase
level of 250 U/L.
Which of the following is most likely the cause of this patient's symptoms?
Statin-induced myopathy is rare and manifests as unexplained proximal muscle pain or weakness with an increase in serum creatine kinase level.
Discontinuation of the statin most commonly results in a rapid resolution of muscle symptoms and normalization of the serum creatine kinase level.
The most likely diagnosis is statin-induced myopathy (
Option D

). The incidence of statin-induced muscle symptoms is no greater than 1%, and the incidence of myopathy and rhabdomyolysis is less than 0.1%. Statin-induced myopathy manifests as unexplained muscle pain or weakness with an increase in the creatine kinase (CK) level up to 10 times the upper limit of normal (ULN). Statin-induced rhabdomyolysis is a more severely symptomatic form of myopathy with CK levels typically greater than 40 times the ULN. Most patients experience statin-induced myopathy within the first year of therapy after a dose increase or the addition of an interacting drug. Most drugs that interact with statins increase the statin blood concentration and the risk of myopathy/rhabdomyolysis. The typical clinical presentation consists of symmetric muscle pain and weakness, but nonspecific lower back pain has been reported as a feature of statin-induced myopathy. The serum CK level should be measured in patients taking a statin who develop muscle pain or weakness. Delay in making the diagnosis (and stopping the statin) can lead to rhabdomyolysis and possibly acute kidney injury. Discontinuation of the statin most commonly results in a rapid resolution of symptoms and normalization of the serum CK level.
Immune-mediated necrotizing myopathy (IMNM) (
Option A

) presents acutely or subacutely with more severe proximal muscle pain and extremely high CK levels. The vast majority of patients on statins with muscle pain do not have IMNM. This patient with mild symptoms and modest elevation of CK is unlikely to have IMNM.
Polymyalgia rheumatica (
Option B
) is an inflammatory disorder associated with pain and stiffness of the neck, shoulder, and hip girdle. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is invariably elevated but the CK level is normal.
Proximal lumbosacral radiculoneuropathy (
Option C

) is associated with subacute painful involvement of the lumbosacral plexus followed by resolution of pain and onset of marked asymmetric weakness with atrophy and weight loss. It is often associated with diabetes, even when glucose levels are well controlled. The patient's symptoms do not match those of proximal lumbosacral radiculopathy.

references: Newman CB, Preiss D, Tobert JA, et al; American Heart Association Clinical Lipidology, Lipoprotein, Metabolism and Thrombosis Committee, a Joint Committee of the Council on Atherosclerosis, Thrombosis and Vascular Biology and Council on Lifestyle and Cardiometabolic Health; Council on Cardiovascular Disease in the Young; Council on Clinical Cardiology; and Stroke Council. Statin safety and associated adverse events: a scientific statement from the American Heart Association. Arterioscler Thromb Vasc Biol. 2019;39:e38-e81.

title: Question 38

children: An 85-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital after surgical fixation of a broken hip. He reports a mild level of pain. He did not bring his glasses or hearing aids to the hospital. He has been making progress with physical therapy and, when his pain is controlled, he will be transferred to an inpatient rehabilitation facility. His history includes high-frequency hearing loss, macular degeneration, and hypertension. Medications are lisinopril and chlorthalidone.
On physical examination, vital signs and other findings are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate measure to prevent delirium?

text.__html: Monitoring of vital signs every 2 hours
Use of his glasses and hearing aids

children: Identifying and correcting sensory impairments, including providing patients with their visual and hearing aids, is effective in the prevention of delirium.
This patient's glasses and hearing aids should be provided to him to prevent delirium (
Option E

). Delirium is a potentially preventable syndrome associated with other medical disorders, the adverse effects of medication, or drug withdrawal. It is common in hospitalized patients, and elderly patients such as this one are at higher risk postsurgery. Delirium is associated with increases in morbidity, medical complications, hospital length of stay, and rate of discharge to long-term care facilities; prevention is more effective than treatment of delirium, especially in at-risk patients. Identifying and correcting sensory impairments, including providing patients with their visual and hearing aids, is an environmental modification that has been shown to be effective in the prevention of delirium.
Early mobilization prevents delirium, so the patient does not need bedrest (
Option A
) outside of physical therapy.
Checking vital signs every 2 hours would entail awakening the patient throughout the night (
Option B

). Because altered circadian rhythm is a component of the clinical syndrome of delirium, promoting a normal sleep-wake cycle by limiting interruptions during nocturnal sleeping hours, minimizing light and noise at night, and opening curtains and encouraging activity during the daytime is an important element in the prevention of delirium. Finally, frequent monitoring of vital signs may provide early detection of changes in clinical status but will not prevent delirium.

No medication is currently approved by the FDA for the management of delirium, so the use of these agents for such an indication is off-label. Furthermore, there is no strong evidence that any particular drug is useful for delirium prevention. Melatonin may assist in maintaining the sleep-wake cycle. Unless patients are at risk of harm to themselves or others, antipsychotic agents such as quetiapine (
Option C
) should be avoided because psychoactive and sedating medications can contribute to the development of delirium.
Scheduled morphine administration (
Option D
) is likely to overtreat the patient's pain and lead to sedation. It is important to treat pain, but pain should be managed using the least sedating agents possible in patients at risk for delirium.

objective.__html: Prevent delirium in a hospitalized patient.

references: Marcantonio ER. Delirium in hospitalized older adults. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:1456-66.

title: Question 39

children: A 38-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for surgical resection of a glioblastoma. Following resection, he is expected to remain in intensive care for 2 days and discharged home by the third day.
Which of the following is the most appropriate measure to prevent venous thromboembolism immediately following surgery?
Perioperative mechanical venous thromboembolism prophylaxis is a reasonable option for patients undergoing cranial surgery.

Subcutaneous low-molecular-weight heparin added to mechanical venous thromboembolism prophylaxis is reasonable 24 to 48 hours following resection of primary brain tumors for patients whose risk of VTE outweighs their risk of bleeding.
Mechanical prophylaxis (
Option B

) is the most appropriate venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis immediately following cranial surgery. Patients with primary and malignant brain tumors, as with most patients with cancer, are hypercoagulable and predisposed to VTE. The perioperative risk associated with glioma approaches 25% in some studies and prophylaxis should begin on admission to the hospital. Guidelines recommend pharmacologic VTE prophylaxis over mechanical prophylaxis in acutely or critically ill patients. In situations in which pharmacologic prophylaxis cannot be given, such as immediately prior to or following neurosurgery, guidelines recommend mechanical prophylaxis over no prophylaxis. Mechanical prophylaxis choices for patients undergoing cranial surgery include either intermittent pneumatic compression or graduated compression stockings. However, not all guidelines support the use of compression stockings for VTE prophylaxis. The differing recommendations relate to the quality of evidence and values assigned to benefits and harms. Recent guidelines recommend continuation of mechanical prophylaxis following cranial surgery for 30 days or until the patient is mobile or discharged, whichever is sooner. The addition of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) starting 24 to 48 hours after cranial surgery and continued for 7 days after surgery is also suggested for patients whose risk of VTE outweighs their risk of bleeding.
In the immediate perioperative period neither LMWH (
Option A
) nor unfractionated heparin (UFH) (
Option C

) is recommended because of the risk of intracerebral bleeding. When anticoagulation can be safely initiated, guidelines suggest LMWH over UF unless there is significant renal impairment (creatinine clearance ≤ 30 mL/min). Studies evaluating the effectiveness of long-term prophylaxis with LMWH in patients with glioma show a trend toward fewer episodes of VTE but more episodes of intracerebral hemorrhage; therefore, long-term therapy is not recommended for most patients with glioma.
Providing no VTE prophylaxis (
Option D

) is not the best option because it places the patient at increased risk for VTE. All guidelines agree that acutely ill medical patients, patients with active cancer, surgical patients, and selected patients with identifiable risk factors should receive VTE prophylaxis during hospitalization.

objective.__html: Prevent venous thromboembolism in patients with primary brain tumors.

references: National Institute for Health and Care Excellence. Venous thromboembolism in over 16s: reducing the risk of hospital-acquired deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism.

children: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng89

references: . Accessed May 2, 2020.

title: Question 40

children: A 31-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-mm saccular aneurysm in the anterior communicating artery found incidentally on a magnetic resonance angiogram of the head obtained to investigate new-onset trigeminal neuralgia. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and has no additional medical problems. His only medication is carbamazepine.
On physical examination, vital signs, general physical and neurologic examinations are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Risk for rupture at 5 years is low for unruptured intracranial arterial aneurysms less than 7 mm in the posterior circulation and less than 12 mm in the anterior circulation.
Annual noninvasive imaging is recommended in patients with an unruptured aneurysm.
The most appropriate management is serial magnetic resonance angiography (
Option E

). This patient has an unruptured intracranial arterial aneurysm that is less than 12 mm in the anterior circulation (anterior cerebral, middle cerebral, and internal carotid arteries). Such aneurysms are associated with a low risk for rupture at 5 years. Aneurysms that are less than 7 mm in the posterior circulation (posterior communicating and basilar arteries) have a similarly low risk for rupture. Factors associated with increased risk for rupture include rapid growth detected over serial imaging, active tobacco use, and uncontrolled hypertension. Other predictors of aneurysmal rupture that should prompt surgical consideration include a previous aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage, rapid aneurysm growth, or the presence of cranial nerve palsy. Annual noninvasive imaging is recommended in patients with an unruptured aneurysm. CT or MRI angiography can be considered for serial imaging because they are both noninvasive, with CT usually performed in patients who cannot undergo MRI. Additional noninvasive testing on a yearly basis should be performed to track aneurysm growth, which may be a predictor for rupture.
Aneurysm clipping and coiling (
Options A and B

) are not indicated because this patient's risk for rupture is low, and the associated neurologic disability and morbidity with intervention are high. In patients with a ruptured aneurysm, neurosurgical clipping versus endovascular coiling has similar success at occlusion of the aneurysm, and the choice of one modality over another is dictated by aneurysm shape and location and by operator experience.
Because it is invasive, catheter-based angiography (
Option C
) is not routinely indicated for imaging of aneurysms unless further treatment is planned on the basis of features that could help predict rupture. CT angiography (
Option D
) is also incorrect because an additional test is not likely to reveal a change in the size of the aneurysm, and CT is associated with risks from radiation and contrast medium.

references: Thompson BG, Brown RD Jr, Amin-Hanjani S, et al; American Heart Association Stroke Council, Council on Cardiovascular and Stroke Nursing, and Council on Epidemiology and Prevention. Guidelines for the Management of Patients With Unruptured Intracranial Aneurysms: A Guideline for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. Stroke. 2015;46:2368-400.

title: Question 41

children: An 84-year-old man is evaluated for an 18-month history of increasing forgetfulness and one episode of getting lost while driving on a familiar route. He lost his car keys and had to have a new set made. He lives with his spouse and is independent in all of his instrumental and basic activities of daily living. He and his spouse report no signs and symptoms of depression. In high school and in college he was on the boxing team. He is otherwise well and takes no medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. His Montreal Cognitive Assessment score is 21/30, with difficulty copying the cube, recalling the five words, and naming the day, date, and month noted.
Depression screening is negative.
Brain MRI shows significant hippocampal atrophy bilaterally with minimal white matter hyperintensities.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment requires a subjective report of a decline in cognitive abilities with relative preservation of day-to-day function and evidence of cognitive impairment on cognitive testing.

The patient has the typical clinical history, cognitive screening results, and imaging findings of Alzheimer disease. However, his functional status is independent in all instrumental and basic activities of daily living. The diagnosis of mild cognitive impairment (MCI) (
Option B

) includes patients with clear symptoms of cognitive decline who do not meet criteria for dementia. The formal criteria for MCI are a subjective report (from either the patient or a witness) of a decline in cognitive abilities with relative preservation of day-to-day function and evidence of cognitive impairment on cognitive testing. Because of wide variability in the risk of progression, steps should be taken to confirm the underlying cause of the symptoms. In patients with cognitive impairment lasting more than 3 months, evaluation should include laboratory testing for potentially reversible conditions. Examples include assessment for medication adverse events, sleep apnea, depression, and other common medical conditions and an MRI without contrast.
MRI of the brain supports the diagnosis of Alzheimer disease (
Option A

) when it shows evidence of decreased volume of the hippocampi, although this is a nonspecific finding. When seen in MCI, decreased hippocampal volume predicts a higher likelihood of progression to Alzheimer dementia. Because of his independence in activities of daily living, this patient does not have Alzheimer dementia.
Traumatic encephalopathy syndrome (TES) (
Option C

) is the progressive neurodegenerative syndrome associated with repetitive head trauma. Supportive clinical features include emotional dysregulation, behavior change, and motor disturbance with parkinsonian features. Global brain atrophy may be seen on brain imaging. This patient does not have the clinical or imaging characteristics of TES.
The likelihood of vascular cognitive impairment (
Option D

) increases with age and is associated with systemic vascular risk factors and a history of stroke. In vascular cognitive impairment, MRIs typically display a pattern of diffuse and confluent changes in the white matter of the brain. This patient's lack of risk factors and MRI are not supportive of vascular cognitive impairment.

references: Petersen RC, Lopez O, Armstrong MJ, et al. Practice guideline update summary: mild cognitive impairment: report of the Guideline Development, Dissemination, and Implementation Subcommittee of the American Academy of Neurology. Neurology. 2018;90:126-35.

title: Question 42

children: A 48-year-old man is taken to the emergency department with a 3-month history of progressive headaches, double vision, and slurred speech. On arrival, he has a sudden decline in mentation, becomes comatose, and is emergently intubated.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 188/96 mm Hg, pulse rate is 48/min, and respiration rate is 10/min. The patient is comatose, with large unreactive pupils bilaterally, has no spontaneous movements, and withdraws his upper and lower limbs from noxious stimuli.

Head CT shows a midline thalamic mass extending downward into the upper brainstem with associated parenchymal and intraventricular hemorrhage. There is associated edema and mass effect on the brainstem, leading to compression of brainstem and crowding of the foramen magnum.
The patient's head of the bed is elevated to 30 degrees, hyperventilation with mechanical ventilation in initiated, and intravenous dexamethasone is administered.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional emergent management?

Emergency treatment of increased intracranial pressure with impending herniation and death include elevation of the head of the bed, hyperventilation, dexamethasone (for patients with peritumoral edema), and osmotic diuresis with hypertonic saline or mannitol.

The patient has a brainstem tumor with associated acute hemorrhage and edema, leading to herniation. Brain herniation inevitably leads to death if unrecognized or not properly treated. It manifests as an abrupt decline in mental status, unreactive dilated pupils, and motor weakness with flexor or extensor posturing. This patient also demonstrates the Cushing response (bradycardia and hypertension), a sign of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). Emergent treatment includes elevation of the head of the bed to 30 degrees, hyperventilation (usually with mechanical ventilation) to an arterial P
CO
of 20 to 25 mm Hg (2.7-3.3 kPa), infusion of either hypertonic saline or mannitol (
Option C

), and administration of dexamethasone (for patients with peritumoral edema). Mannitol is a diuretic that reduces brain edema by osmotically transferring water from brain tissue into the circulation, where it is renally excreted. The impact of mannitol on ICP is evident within minutes and peaks in 1 hour. These treatments can be life-saving and often are used as a bridge to emergent surgery.
Bevacizumab (
Option A

) is an antiangiogenic agent that is used in the treatment of a variety of tumors, including tumors metastatic to the brain. Antiangiogenic agents may reduce ICP by a number of mechanisms including inhibiting angiogenesis and minimizing vasogenic edema. However, these agents take weeks or months to have an effect and are not a good option in an emergency situation.
Decompressive craniotomy (
Option B

) can be considered in this setting, and it would certainly be a more definitive measure. However, the other acute measures are a necessary bridge to emergent surgery. These measures are temporizing but can be life-saving.
Intravenous 0.9% saline (
Option D
) is likely to increase ICP and should not be used.

references: Phillips KA, Fadul CE, Schiff D. Neurologic and medical management of brain tumors. Neurol Clin. 2018;36(3):449-466.

title: Question 43

children: An 82-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of progressively worsening repetitive questioning, one episode of getting lost while driving on a familiar route, and repeated instances of losing her cell phone. She lives alone and is independent in all of her basic activities of daily living, except that her daughter has automated her finances because of some errors.
On physical examination, vital signs are normal and other findings are unremarkable. The Mini–Mental State Examination score is 23.
An MRI of the brain shows significant hippocampal atrophy bilaterally with minimal white matter hyperintensities.
Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
The acetylcholinesterase inhibitors donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine are approved for treating mild to moderate dementia in patients with Alzheimer disease.
Memantine is used as an adjunct to an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor in the moderate to severe stage of Alzheimer disease.
The most appropriate treatment is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, such as donepezil (
Option A

). One tool used to categorize dementia into levels of severity is the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score. Mild dementia is often associated with a MMSE score of 20 to 23, moderate dementia a score of 10 to 19, and severe dementia a score <10. This patient is in a mild stage of dementia due to Alzheimer disease (AD), given her abnormal test score and her functional dependence with her finances. AD is the most common memory-predominant dementia and is also the most common cause of dementia. The typical presentation of AD is that of an insidious worsening of memory, language, and visuospatial abilities. Manifestations include forgetfulness, frequent repetition of questions or statements, word-finding difficulties, hesitation in speech, and navigational problems. The acetylcholinesterase inhibitors donepezil, rivastigmine, and galantamine are approved for treating mild-to-moderate dementia in patients with AD and have demonstrated modest benefits in cognitive performance, stabilizing progression of symptoms, and functional loss. Because of their possible adverse effects on conduction, acetylcholinesterase inhibitors should be used with caution or avoided in patients with bradycardia or other conduction abnormalities. The most common adverse effects are gastrointestinal issues, which result in discontinuation of the medication in nearly 20% of patients. Additional adverse effects include syncope, agitation, nocturnal cramps, and vivid dreams. Donepezil should be used with caution in patients with a history of seizures.
Supplements such as Ginkgo biloba (
Option B
) and high-dose vitamin E (
Option C

) have not shown clinical benefit in studies. Therapy with Ginkgo biloba is also limited because there is no standardization of dose or regulation of content by the FDA. High-dose vitamin E has been associated with an increase in all-cause mortality and heart failure in some studies.
Memantine (
Option D
) is an
N
-methyl-
D

-aspartate receptor antagonist that is FDA-approved for use in AD as an adjunct to an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor in the moderate to severe stage of dementia due to AD. There is no evidence of benefit in the mild stage of AD dementia. Memantine has fewer adverse effects than acetylcholinesterase inhibitors and is not associated with adverse cardiovascular effects. The most commonly reported side effect is dizziness.

references: Oh ES, Rabins PV. Dementia.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 44

children: A 66-year-old man is evaluated for abnormal behavior during sleep. His wife reports he has a prolonged history of nocturnal flailing and jerking movements and of shouting, punching, and jumping out of bed. The patient does not recall these movements and reports no discomfort. He also has a history of urinary incontinence and falls. He takes no medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. He has reduced facial expression and bilateral rigidity. His gait is unsteady, with postural imbalance during turns, and he cannot walk in tandem. Other neurologic examination findings are unremarkable.
A polysomnogram reveals complex movements associated with preserved muscle tone during rapid-eye-movement sleep.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: Rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder

children: Rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder is caused by loss of normal paralysis during the rapid eye movement phase of sleep, leading to violent movements and shouting.
RBD has a strong association with neurodegenerative disorders including Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and dementia with Lewy bodies and may precede these disorders by decades.
The most likely diagnosis is rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder (RBD) (
Option C

). This movement disorder is caused by loss of normal paralysis during the rapid eye movement phase of sleep, leading to violent movements and shouting as patients respond to their dreams. Patients are often unaware of the movements; these are typically reported by their bed partners. RBD is sometimes brought to attention as a result of injuries sustained by patients or their bed partners during sleep. RBD has a strong association with neurodegenerative disorders caused by synuclein accumulation, including Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, and dementia with Lewy bodies, and may precede these disorders by decades. In this patient, the report by his wife, sleep study findings, and clinical evidence of a parkinsonian disorder (likely multiple system atrophy given the associated ataxia and dysautonomia) suggest RBD.
Hypnic myoclonus (
Option A
) or sleep starts are physiologic rapid jerky movements experienced at sleep onset. Movements consist of simple jerks and may be associated with a subjective sense of falling from a height.
Periodic limb movement disorder (
Option B

) is a common movement disorder characterized by brief triple flexion movements of the legs that repeat in 20-second periods during sleep. This disorder is not associated with vocalization or complex behavior, such as punching or jumping out of bed, and thus is not a likely diagnosis in this patient.
Restless legs syndrome (
Option D

) is unlikely because the patient reports no subjective discomfort or making voluntary movements to relieve an urge. In addition, restless leg symptoms occur at night and with rest but when patients are awake.
Vivid dreams (
Option E

) are not associated with involuntary movements (acting out) during sleep. Vivid dreams are experienced sporadically by most people. In a patient with RBD, vivid dreams may trigger a pronounced or violent reaction as patients act out an escape or fight.

objective.__html: Diagnose rapid eye movement sleep behavior disorder.

references: Dauvilliers Y, Schenck CH, Postuma RB, et al. REM sleep behaviour disorder. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2018;4:19.

title: Question 45

children: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated for a diffuse pruritic rash that began 2 days ago and initially involved the torso. Today the rash has spread to the upper and lower extremities and back. She began lamotrigine therapy 6 weeks ago for epilepsy and discontinued it yesterday. She denies ocular symptoms, sores in her mouth, or fever. She is minimally symptomatic. She has no other medical problems and takes no other medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. There is a patchy, erythematous maculopapular rash on the upper and lower extremities, torso, and back. There is no involvement of the mucosa, palms, or soles. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Complete blood count with differential and a comprehensive metabolic panel are normal.
Diphenhydramine is prescribed.
Which of the following is the most appropriate seizure management?
Lamotrigine may cause a morbilliform rash, which most commonly resolves with discontinuation of the drug but sometimes may be severe and life-threatening.
Gabapentin is a first-line medication for treating epilepsy in older adults; it has a low incidence of rash and other allergic reactions and good evidence of efficacy.
The most appropriate seizure management is to initiate gabapentin (
Option B

). This elderly patient likely has a lamotrigine-related rash. Lamotrigine may cause a morbiliform rash, which most commonly resolves with discontinuation of the drug but sometimes may be severe and life-threatening. This patient's rash is likely not a serious rash based on the lack of mucosal involvement, lymphadenopathy, and systemic features, including fever. Reassuring laboratory findings include the absence of eosinophilia and normal aminotransaminase levels. Morbilliform reactions are the most common drug reactions and are most likely a type IV delayed hypersensitivity reaction. As such, the rash appears in the first or second week after drug exposure. Patients develop pink papules and macules that coalesce symmetrically to form plaques. The papules are often dense and monomorphic and are accompanied by varying degrees of pruritus beginning on the trunk and progressing distally across the limbs. Palms and soles are usually spared. Treatment involves cessation of the causative agent, systemic and/or topical glucocorticoids, and oral H1 antihistamines. Any patient taking an antiepileptic drug should be counseled to stop their medication and to contact their clinician if a rash develops, and seek emergency care if fevers, skin pain, blisters, pustules, or mucous membrane involvement is present, indicating serious and potentially life-threating conditions such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome/toxic epidermal necrolysis. Gabapentin has a low incidence of rash and other allergic reactions and also has good evidence of efficacy in focal epilepsy in older adults; thus, it is the most appropriate replacement for lamotrigine.
In addition to lamotrigine, phenobarbital, phenytoin, and carbamazepine (
Options A, C, and D

) are all known to cause rash. The rash may be severe and life-threatening and occur at an incidence high enough that these drugs should be avoided, especially in patients with prior drug rash (owing to cross-reactivity), unless no other good medication options are available.

objective.__html: Treat epilepsy in an elderly patient with a history of seizure medication–related rash.

references: Mani R, Monteleone C, Schalock PC, et al. Rashes and other hypersensitivity reactions associated with antiepileptic drugs: A review of current literature. Seizure. 2019;71:270-278.

title: Question 46

children: A 62-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for right arm weakness that lasted 20 minutes and occurred 6 hours ago. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications are metformin, lisinopril, and hydrochlorothiazide.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 142/82 mm Hg; the remainder of the vital signs and neurologic examination are normal.
Hemoglobin A
1c
value is 6.5%, and LDL cholesterol level is 120 mg/dL (3.1 mmol/L). Basic metabolic profile and aminotransferase levels are normal.
CT scan of the head shows no acute ischemic changes. Carotid duplex ultrasound shows less than 40% stenosis in both carotid arteries and normal flow in the vertebral arteries.
High-intensity rosuvastatin is initiated.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?

In patients who have experienced a transient ischemic attack, adding clopidogrel to aspirin for 21 days has been shown to be effective in reducing the risk for subsequent stroke compared with monotherapy with either agent alone.
In patients treated with dual antiplatelet therapy following a transient ischemic attack or minor stroke, aspirin should be continued following discontinuation of clopidogrel at 21 days.
