Subarachnoid hemorrhage, the most common cause of thunderclap headache, is discovered in nearly 25% of affected patients. Noncontrast head CT should be performed without delay. The differential diagnosis of thunderclap headache also includes intracranial venous or sinus thrombosis, cervical artery dissection, reversible cerebral vasoconstriction syndrome, posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome, and ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack.
Brain MRI (
Option A

) is preferred to head CT in the evaluation of subacute or chronic headaches, given its greater sensitivity and safety. In the acute setting, however, head CT is performed more rapidly and may be more accurate in identifying acute intracranial hemorrhage.
Lumbar puncture (
Option C

) with measurement of opening pressure, cell counts, and xanthochromia should be performed if the head CT is nondiagnostic. Lumbar puncture is considered only after a screening neuroimaging study because acute hydrocephalus or space-occupying lesions could present with thunderclap onset and an elevated risk for herniation during a lumbar puncture procedure.
Sumatriptan (
Option D

) is an effective treatment for acute migraine, but this presentation is atypical for migraine. The use of sumatriptan would also be contraindicated within 24 hours of the administration of rizatriptan. Additionally, a response to triptans should not be a diagnostic indicator for migraine because some secondary headaches may respond to subcutaneous sumatriptan.

objective.__html: Evaluate a patient with a thunderclap headache.

references: Godwin SA, Cherkas DS, Panagos PD, et al; American College of Emergency Physicians Clinical Policies Subcommittee (Writing Committee) on Acute Headache: Clinical Policy: Critical Issues in the Evaluation and Management of Adult Patients Presenting to the Emergency Department With Acute Headache. Ann Emerg Med. 2019;74:e41-e74.
doi:10.1016/j.annemergmed.2019.07.009

title: Question 92

children: A 38-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-year history of headache. Headache episodes occur three times per month, each lasting approximately 8 hours and sometimes up to 3 days. She describes midfrontal pressure that spreads bilaterally and becomes both stabbing and throbbing over 1 to 2 hours, worsening with her usual activities and becoming so severe that she must lie down. Headaches are occasionally accompanied by nausea and nasal congestion but no visual or neurologic symptoms. Combined naproxen-pseudoephedrine provides partial symptom relief.
All physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Migraine is the most common severe headache.

Established criteria for migraine include recurrent attacks of head pain lasting from 4 to 72 hours without treatment, involving at least two of four features (unilateral location, throbbing nature, moderate-severe intensity, worsening with routine physical activity), and possessing at least one of the following two associations: (1) nausea and/or vomiting and (2) photophobia and phonophobia.
The most likely diagnosis is migraine (
Option B

). Migraine is the most common severe headache in both population-based and clinic-based studies. Annual prevalence for migraine approximates 13% of adults, and greater than 90% of headache visits to primary care and specialty settings involve migraine. According to criteria published in the International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition, migraine involves recurrent attacks (at least 5 lifetime) of head pain lasting, without treatment, from 4 to 72 hours. The pain of migraine involves at least two of four features (unilateral location, throbbing nature, moderate to severe intensity, worsening with routine physical activity) and is associated with at least one of two features: (1) nausea and/or vomiting and (2) photophobia and phonophobia. Neurologic examination is typically normal. Migraine may be subclassified qualitatively (with or without aura) and quantitatively (episodic or chronic). Migraine in patients reporting visual or neurologic symptoms meeting appropriate criteria will be subclassified as migraine with aura, but very few patients with migraine will ever experience aura. The number of total headache days per month differentiates episodic (<15 days) from chronic (15 or more days) migraine. Because of the extensive phenotypic variation, nearly half of migraine presentations are misdiagnosed. Neck pain (75%) and “sinus” symptoms, such as tearing or nasal drainage (50%), are both more common than features felt to be characteristic of migraine, such as vomiting or aura.
Cluster headache (
Option A

) may be severe or throbbing and may result in nausea and nasal congestion or drainage. However, cluster headache pain is strictly unilateral, and attacks by definition do not extend beyond 3 hours without treatment.
Primary stabbing (
Option C

) headache involves episodes of stabbing head pain lasting seconds and occurring in isolation or in series. There are no associated autonomic features. The attacks described by this patient are much longer in duration. The location of pain is fixed in one third of patients and extratrigeminal in most patients. Indomethacin can be helpful during cycles of more frequent attacks.
Nausea, severe intensity, throbbing quality, and resultant disability from headache pain are not features seen with tension-type headache (
Option D

references: MacGregor EA. Migraine.

children: Ann Intern Med

title: Question 93

children: A 19-year-old woman is evaluated for a 1-year history of recurrent stereotyped episodes of loss of consciousness and subsequent shaking, most of which have been precipitated by standing for prolonged periods in hot weather. She typically has a warning symptom of tunnel vision followed by diminished hearing, nausea, pallor, and a fall associated with loss of consciousness. Witnesses of these events have noted intermittent twitching of all four limbs, with each limb shaking independently. Within 45 seconds, the patient awakens feeling alert, oriented, and able to continue normal conversation.
All physical examination findings, including vital signs, are unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Syncope is a transient loss of consciousness and postural tone due to global cerebral hypoperfusion that typically has an abrupt onset and complete, rapid neurologic recovery.
Nonepileptic myoclonus and other types of movements and shaking are typical of convulsive syncope.
The patient most likely has convulsive syncope (
Option B

). Syncope is a transient complete loss of consciousness and postural tone due to global cerebral hypoperfusion and may follow stereotyped patterns (as can seizures or migraines). Its onset is abrupt, with a spontaneous, rapid, and complete recovery. The most common cause of syncope is neurally mediated syncope, which generally occurs with prolonged standing or dehydration and has a prodrome of nausea, lightheadedness, warmth, tunnel vision, or palpitations. Stereotyped events with warning signs can be mistaken for seizures, but the duration of loss of consciousness is usually briefer in syncope (<1 min) than in seizures, and immediate and complete neurologic recovery is typical. Nonepileptic myoclonus (in this patient) and other types of movements and shaking are typical of convulsive syncope; in fact, syncope without any movements is the exception rather than the rule.
Atonic seizures (
Option A

) are characterized by abrupt falling, a brief loss of consciousness, and decreased tone; there usually are no warning symptoms, such as tunnel vision or palpitations, or precipitating events such as prolonged standing. The duration of atonic seizures is briefer (a few seconds) than that of syncope.
Generalized tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS) (
Option C

) are characterized by an abrupt loss of consciousness sometimes associated with a scream or choking sound, and increased tone at onset (tonic phase), followed by rhythmic, synchronous jerking of all limbs (clonic phase) lasting usually more than 1 minute. Confusion, lethargy, and occasionally combativeness follow GTCS. Cyanosis, not pallor, is common with this type of seizure.
Myoclonus (
Option D

) is a single quick jerk of a limb or the entire body lasting less than a second and is not always associated with a seizure. A diagnosis of myoclonic seizures can be confirmed by electroencephalography, with each jerk associated with a generalized spike-and-wave discharge. Myoclonic seizures also can occur repetitively and result in falls. Awareness is maintained and duration is very short (<1 second), which differentiates it from convulsive syncope.

references: Sheldon R. How to differentiate syncope from seizure. Cardiol Clin. 2015;33(3):377–385.

title: Question 94

children: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department for a 2-day history of worsening lower extremity weakness, fatigue, and a return of urinary frequency. She has secondary progressive multiple sclerosis with gait dysfunction, leg weakness, and poor vision. She uses a walker. She also has an overactive bladder with symptoms of urgency and frequency previously well controlled on solifenacin. Additional medications are fluoxetine and a vitamin D supplement.

On physical examination, temperature is 38.4 °C (101.1 °F), blood pressure is 110/50 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 70/min. Muscle strength testing shows normal strength in the upper extremities and 3/5 strength in the lower extremities with increased tone. She is unable to support her weight independently when she stands from a seated position. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

text.__html: Obtain MRI of the cervical and thoracic spines

children: Patients with multiple sclerosis experience Uhthoff phenomenon, in which chronic neurologic symptoms become more prominent in the setting of elevated body temperature.
The most appropriate next step in management is to obtain a urinalysis and urine culture (
Option E

). This patient has secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (MS) with worsening neurologic function, which suggests a potential MS relapse or disability progression. However, she also has urinary frequency and an elevated body temperature, which is suggestive of a urinary tract infection, possibly an upper tract infection. Many patients with multiple sclerosis experience Uhthoff phenomenon, in which chronic neurologic symptoms become more prominent in the setting of elevated body temperature (hot weather, physical exertion, or fever). Because this patient has pre-existing lower extremity weakness, she is likely experiencing Uhthoff phenomenon (or a “pseudorelapse”) caused by a urinary tract infection–associated fever and not a new inflammatory lesion in her brain or spinal cord.
Increasing this patient's solifenacin dose (
Option A
) is not the most appropriate management at this time; her urinary frequency is likely being worsened by an underlying urinary tract infection.
Initiating intravenous high-dose glucocorticoids (
Option B

) is appropriate therapy for an MS relapse. However, there is a higher likelihood that her worsening symptoms are caused by Uhthoff phenomenon, which is masquerading as a relapse. Diagnosing and treating the underlying cause of her fever is the most appropriate next step. Symptoms that persist despite treatment of the infection and fever may represent a relapse, and intravenous glucocorticoids would be a reasonable consideration.
The stimulant medications modafinil (
Option C

), armodafinil, amantadine, and amphetamines may be helpful in managing chronic fatigue. Although this patient's fatigue may be improved by modafinil, it is likely caused by an underlying infection and may resolve with treatment of the infection.
An MRI of the cervical and thoracic spine (
Option D

) could potentially help determine if her worsened lower extremity weakness is caused by the formation of a new MS lesion. However, in the setting of a possible infection, evaluation and treatment of the infection has a higher utility and significantly lower cost than this imaging test.

objective.__html: Manage a suspected pseudorelapse of multiple sclerosis.

references: Jain A, Rosso M, Santoro JD. Wilhelm Uhthoff and Uhthoff's phenomenon. Mult Scler. 2019:1352458519881950.

title: Question 95

children: A 67-year-old man is evaluated for a 1-minute episode of right-sided weakness and aphasia that occurred yesterday. The patient also has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin.

On physical examination, blood pressure is 164/100 mm Hg; all other vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rhythm; no murmurs or carotid bruits are heard on cardiac auscultation. A neurologic examination has normal findings.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next diagnostic test?

text.__html: Magnetic resonance angiography of the brain

children: The risk of stroke after a TIA is highest in patients with extracranial internal carotid artery stenosis.
Carotid ultrasonography should be performed emergently in patients with transient ischemic attack to identify those who may benefit from surgery.
This patient should next undergo carotid ultrasonography (
Option A
). He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) characterized by the focal neurologic symptom of hemiparesis. The patient has an ABCD

score (Age > 60 years, elevated Blood pressure, Clinical presentation of hemiparesis, Duration of symptoms, and Diabetes mellitus) of 5, which indicates a high risk of stroke at 48 hours (4.1%) and 90 days (9.8%). The highest risk of stroke after a TIA or minor stroke is associated with symptomatic large artery atherosclerosis in patients with extracranial internal carotid artery stenosis. These patients benefit from urgent carotid revascularization to prevent a subsequent stroke. Carotid ultrasonography is a low-cost, readily available test not associated with radiation and should be performed emergently in order to identify patients who may require surgery.
Electroencephalography (
Option B
) is not appropriate because the patient does not have other symptoms of epilepsy, such as convulsions or loss of awareness.
Magnetic resonance angiography (
Option C

) is an expensive test and may not immediately change management. Intracranial atherosclerosis is associated with a high risk of stroke after a TIA and minor stroke, and the indicated treatment for stroke prevention is best medical therapy. Intracranial stenting is high risk without a significant reduction in stroke. MRI of the brain also will not result in an immediate change in management and is high cost. The latest American Heart Association guidelines do not recommend routine use of MRI in the inpatient setting; an infarct present on MRI will not change recommendations on initiation of antithrombotic treatment or necessarily inform risk of stroke better than the less expensive carotid imaging. After the initial diagnostic testing, an MRI may allow for further stroke subtyping and confirm the diagnosis of minor stroke.
Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) (
Option D

) has a low yield for identifying source of emboli in patients with stroke who have no risk factors and is not routinely indicated as the initial cardiac diagnostic test. A TEE can be considered in patients who are younger than 45 years who have otherwise negative diagnostic testing, including transthoracic echocardiography (TTE). TTE also is not routinely indicated in patients with stroke unless there is a clinical suspicion of a cardioembolic stroke based on medical history or examination findings.

references: Powers WJ, Rabinstein AA, Ackerson T, et al; American Heart Association Stroke Council. 2018 Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke: A Guideline for Healthcare Professionals From the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association. Stroke. 2018;49:e46-e110.

title: Question 96

children: A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for a 3-month history of repeated rapid and jerky movements on the left side of her face. The movements are painless, and she does not experience any unusual sensation or urge before them. She cannot suppress the movements. She reports no history of involuntary movements or exposure to psychoactive medications.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. She exhibits fast and synchronous contraction of the muscles of facial expression that repeat at irregular intervals. On the left side, during each contraction the eye is closed, the eyebrow is raised, and the corner of the mouth is pulled. There is no facial weakness or sensory loss. The rest of the neurologic examination is normal.
MRI of the brain reveals focal compression of left cranial nerve VII at its exit zone from the brainstem.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Myoclonus is characterized by brief, shock-like, and jerky contractions that may originate from any part of the nervous system.
Dystonia can be differentiated from myoclonus on the basis of slow and sustained muscle contractions.
The most likely diagnosis is myoclonus (
Option C

). This patient exhibits focal myoclonus of the left side of the face, also known as hemifacial spasm. Myoclonus is characterized by brief, shock-like, and jerky contractions that may originate from any part of the nervous system, including the cortex, subcortical structures, spine, or peripheral nerves. Myoclonus can be physiologic (hiccups, hypnic jerks at sleep onset) or pathologic (caused by medications, toxins, or systemic or central disease). Hemifacial spasm is often caused by vascular compression of cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) at its exit zone from the brainstem. Irritation of the facial nerve leads to synchronous activation of the muscles of facial expression that are innervated by this nerve. This condition can be treated with carbamazepine, botulinum toxin injections, and vascular decompression surgery.
Chorea (
Option A
) consists of random, nonrepetitive, and flowing movements. This patient's rapid, jerky, synchronous, and uniform movements are inconsistent with chorea.
Dystonia (
Option B

) can be differentiated from myoclonus on the basis of slow and sustained muscle contractions. Focal dystonia can affect periorbital muscles (blepharospasm, usually bilateral) or lower facial muscles (oromandibular dystonia). This patient has rapid, brief facial movements that are not characteristic of dystonia.
Stereotypy (
Option D

) is associated with complex, coordinated, and ritualistic movements that are repeated in prolonged cycles. It is often associated with developmental delay and neurometabolic syndromes. Thus, stereotypy is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.
Like myoclonus, tics (
Option E
) can be fast and twitchy. However, tics are often associated with an early age of onset (during childhood), presence of premonitory urges, and suppressibility, which are absent in this patient.

references: Chaudhry N, Srivastava A, Joshi L. Hemifacial spasm: The past, present and future. J Neurol Sci. 2015;356:27-31.
